abstract.p: Letter from Andrew J Imparato, American Assn of People With Disabilities, says Pres Bush and Congress must address unmet needs of students with disabilities (Jan 23 article)

block.p: Re ''Education Plan by Bush Shows New Consensus'' (front page, Jan. 23):
Re ''Education Plan by Bush Shows New Consensus'' (front page, Jan. 23):
As Congress and the Bush administration work to ''leave no child behind'' in reforming education, they must address the unmet needs of students with disabilities.

Data from the Department of Education show that national graduation rates for students who receive special education have stagnated at 27 percent for the last three years, while rates are 75 percent for students who do not rely on special education.

Schools and policy makers must remedy the shortcomings of our special education system. Increased federal financing for special education, coupled with meaningful federal enforcement of the Individuals With Disabilities Education Act, would be a good start.
ANDREW J. IMPARATO President, American Association of People With Disabilities Washington, Jan. 26, 2001
